planets.title: near the sun
planets.name: Mercury
planets.summary: The innermost planet in the Solar System is a dense, heavily cratered world that takes about 59 Earth days to fully rotate on its own axis as it travels on its 88-day journey around the Sun.
planets.description: Mercury is the smallest and closest to the Sun, with an orbital period of about 88 Earth days. Seen from Earth, it appears to move around its orbit in about 116 days, which is much faster than any other planet in the Solar System. It has no known natural satellites. The planet is named after the Roman deity Mercury, the messenger to the gods..

planets.title: hot melted lava
planets.name: Venus
planets.summary: Venus, the second planet from the sun, is named for the Roman goddess of love and beauty. The planet, the only planet named after a female, may have been named for the most beautiful deity of her pantheon because it shone the brightest of the five planets known to ancient astronomers.
planets.description:
Venus, the second planet from the sun, is named for the Roman goddess of love and beauty. The planet, the only planet named after a female, may have been named for the most beautiful deity of her pantheon because it shone the brightest of the five planets known to ancient astronomers.

In ancient times, Venus was often thought to be two different stars, the evening star and the morning star — that is, the ones that first appeared at sunset and sunrise. In Latin, they were respectively known as Vesper and Lucifer. In Christian times, Lucifer, or light-bringer, became known as the name of Satan before his fall.

planets.title: just right
planets.name: Earth
planets.summary: Earth, also called the world and, less frequently, Gaia (and Terra in some works of science fiction) is the third planet from the Sun, the densest planet in the Solar System, the largest of the Solar System's four terrestrial planets, and the only astronomical object known to accommodate life. The earliest life on Earth arose at least 3.5 billion years ago. Earth's biodiversity has expanded continually except when interrupted by mass extinctions. Although scholars estimate that over 99 percent of all species of life (over five billion)[31] that ever lived on Earth are extinct, there are still an estimated 10–14 million extant species, of which about 1.2 million have been documented and over 86 percent have not yet been described. Over 7.3 billion humans depend upon its biosphere and minerals. Earth's human population is divided among about two hundred sovereign states which interact through diplomacy, conflict, travel, trade and communication media..
